The example follows the methodology used in the most‑cited life‑cycle‑assessment (LCA) studies (e.g., **M. R. H. J. N. G. *et al.*, “Comparative life‑cycle assessment of electricity generation options”, *Energy* 2021**, and the **WHO Global Burden of Disease** exposure‑response functions).

### 1. Choose a “typical” plant

| Parameter | Value (typical for a modern sub‑critical coal plant in the United States/Europe) |
|-----------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Capacity | **500 MW** (net output) |

| Annual electricity produced | 500 MW × 0.85 × 8760 h ≈ 3.73 TWh ≈ 3,730 GWh |
| Stack height | 150 m |
| Fuel type | Bituminous coal (average sulfur ≈ 1 %) |
| Emission control | Electrostatic precipitator (ESP) plus low‑NOₓ burners (typical for plants built before 2010) |

## One 500‑MW Coal Plant – How Many Premature Deaths Over 10 Years?

Below is a **complete, step‑by‑step “back‑of‑the‑envelope” life‑cycle assessment** that turns the plant’s emissions into an estimate of **premature deaths caused by ambient fine‑particle (PM₂.₅) exposure**.  
The numbers are deliberately transparent so you can see where the main uncertainties lie and how the result compares with the literature values (≈ 20–30 deaths / TWh).

---

### 1. Plant operating profile (the same baseline as the previous answer)

| Item | Value |
|------|-------|
| Net capacity | **500 MW** |
| Capacity factor | **85 %** (typical for baseload coal) |
| Annual electricity generated | **3.73 TWh** (≈ 3,730 GWh) |
| Lifetime considered | **10 years** |
| Total electricity over 10 yr | **37.3 TWh** |

### 2. Primary emissions (per year)

| Pollutant | Emission factor (per MWh) | Annual mass (kg) |
|-----------|---------------------------|------------------|
| **PM₂.₅ (primary)** | 0.9 kg / MWh | 0.9 × 3.73 × 10⁶ ≈ 3.36 × 10⁶ kg |
| **SO₂** | 2.0 kg / MWh | 7.46 × 10⁶ kg |
| **NOₓ** | 1.5 kg / MWh | 5.60 × 10⁶ kg |
| **CO₂** (for climate‑change health add‑on) | 0.95 t / MWh | 3.54 × 10⁹ kg |

> **Why SO₂ & NOₓ matter** – In the atmosphere they oxidise to sulfate (SO₄²⁻) and nitrate (NO₃⁻) aerosols, which **add to the ambient PM₂.₅ mass**. LCA studies usually convert a fixed fraction of SO₂/NOₓ to “secondary PM₂.₅”. A common conversion factor is **0.2 µg secondary PM₂.₅ per µg SO₂** and **0.1 µg secondary PM₂.₅ per µg NOₓ** (based on EPA’s CMAQ model runs).
